Principles

A curious thing about business is how much time everyone spends trying to predict them. But the most reliable predictor remains deceptively simple: understanding what matters to the other party.

When you know someone‚Äôs priorities ‚Äì what they optimize for, what they‚Äôll sacrifice, what they consider non-negotiable ‚Äì you can predict their behavior with surprising accuracy.

This is also why we‚Äôre transparent about these principles. Not just as a statement of values (though they are that), but as a practical courtesy. When you understand what drives our decisions, working together becomes less like forecasting market movements and more like calculating compound interest ‚Äì still involving some variables, but fundamentally predictable.

#1 Collaboration

Genious feature of markets is that they‚Äôre not zero-sum, despite what trading floor culture might suggest. The most successful transactions create value for everyone involved. This is why collaboration means solving shared problems rather than engaging in institutional tug-of-war competitions.

Growing the entire pie tends to be more lucrative than tactical maneuvers to secure 3% more of a shrinking one. Simple arithmetic, really.

#2 Commitment

A thing you might notice about contracts is that they‚Äôre designed to work even when the world doesn‚Äôt cooperate. When you promise to pay back a loan, the contract doesn‚Äôt include an asterisk saying ‚Äúunless something unexpected happens.‚Äù This is actually quite useful. If commitments were optional whenever circumstances changed, we‚Äôd just have suggestions, not agreements.

So we deliver what we promise, even when the weather turns, markets shift, or Mercury goes retrograde. It‚Äôs just cleaner that way.

#3 Efficiency

Regarding efficiency: If you‚Äôve ever watched traders during market hours, you‚Äôll notice they don‚Äôt pause to reorganize their desk drawers or contemplate lunch options. There‚Äôs a reason for this laser focus. When tasks and priorities are clear, energy doesn‚Äôt leak into theoretical discussions about alternative approaches to hypothetical problems that nobody has actually encountered.

#4 Simplification

Complexity, meanwhile, is a bit like leverage ‚Äì useful in specific doses, catastrophic in excess.

Breaking complicated systems into simpler components isn‚Äôt just an engineering preference; it‚Äôs risk management. When something inevitably breaks, you want to isolate the problem without explaining to clients why the entire system is temporarily contemplating its existence.

#5 Automation

As for automation ‚Äì well, humans are wonderful for creativity, judgment, and explaining why quarterly results missed expectations. They‚Äôre less wonderful for performing identical tasks repeatedly with perfect consistency.

Anything that can be automated should be, if only to free up brainpower for the genuinely interesting problems that algorithms can‚Äôt yet solve.

The Outcome

After all, the best business relationships aren‚Äôt about constantly surprising each other. They‚Äôre about being exactly as predictable as promised.

The outcome? Completed projects with predictable results and minimal drama ‚Äì which, coincidentally, is also how the best cooperations are supposed to work.
